sub_title: Software Engineer, Technical Team Leader – Nebius
summary:
Technical team leader with strong algorithmic skills and math background. Extensive experience in distributed storage internals and NoSQL & SQL computational engines. Ready to work on system architecture, technical project management, team management and technical recruitment processes. Formerly, a top-tier participant of programming competitions such as ACM ICPC, IOI, Google Code Jam and TopCoder. 

Since 2015 I work on YTsaurus, an open-source enterprise-level BigData solution, which is able to operate on clusters of tens of thousands of nodes storing exabytes of data. See more at https://ytsaurus.tech

I am also interested in various theoretical computer science areas like combinatorial optimization, linear programming, data structures and algorithms. I had a couple of CS publications while doing my PhD research (unfinished).

treasury_media.title: YTsaurus: Exabyte-Scale Storage and Processing System Is Now Open Source
YTsaurus is a distributed storage and processing platform for Big Data

education.degree_name: Specialist (that is combined BS + MS) in Mathematics

awards.title: IOI 2012 Gold Medal
awards.description: Gold Medal and 7th place of IOI 2012, Italy: https://stats.ioinformatics.org/results/2012

profile_positions.description: I am working on integrating YTsaurus into Nebius cloud infrastructure.
profile_positions.title: Technical Team Leader

profile_positions.description: I am member of the Infrastructure Department of Yandex Data Analysis School. I teach students External Memory Algorithms and Combinatorial Optimization courses.
profile_positions.title: Teacher

profile_positions.description: Same as previous period, but working remotely while travelling the world (temporarily staying in Italy and Serbia as tourist).
profile_positions.title: Technical Team Leader

profile_positions.description:
During this period I become a team leader with 8 full-time engineers in peak + 2-3 interns, some of which were logically divided into subgroups, and some of which were directly mentored by me. I mostly worked on various large projects in MapReduce control plane, YT queue (topic) primitives and on releasing YT as an Open Source product.

Primary achievements:
- Devised and implemented consumer model for YT queues, which are Kafka-like primitives of data streaming; consumer is a persistent state of some exactly-once streaming pipeline over YT queue
- Designed descending sort order support throughout whole YT stack from storage layer to MapReduce compute; implemented it together with one of my team members
- Designed and implemented AB-experiment framework allowing careful enabling and evaluating of new experimental MapReduce features.
- Devised IO tracking layer for cluster-wide IO usage analysis; implemented by one of my engineers
- Designed authentication layer for internal RPC protocol; implemented by one of my engineers
- Assisted on Spark over YT (SPYT) project, which integrates Apache Spark computational engine with YT storage; later I acquired this project when most of its team left company in 2022
- Became one of ~15 members of System Design Interview committee; started conducting 1-2 System Design interviews per week for main Yandex business unit.

As a member of YT Open Source team:
- Together with 2 team leaders and a project manager worked on a roadmap of ~1 year long project of open sourcing a huge YT code base; participated in coordinating work of ~10 involved people
- Worked on choosing public YTsaurus name (which took around 6 months including all legal checks and failed attempts on registering trademarks for already used names)
- Worked on YTsaurus public page
- Written the most part of YTsaurus release post
- Worked preparing of YQL, CHYT and SPYT source code for releasing into open source with respective teams and engineers
profile_positions.title: Technical Team Leader

profile_positions.description:
During this period I was primarily developing a new major "ClickHouse over YT" (abbreviated as CHYT) project, which is a low-level integration of blazing fast and poular ClickHouse computation engine with YT storage. Project ended up as a big success, as of mid-2023 it is used by >1k users within company on daily basis to query data within YT. 

I also kept ownership of MapReduce control plane and became actively involved in hiring process, assessing both interns and full-time candidates. During this period I helped in hiring two engineers, which entered as intern and middle engineers respectively, and later both became senior software engineers under my mentorship.

Primary achievements:
- Devised and implemented architecture of ClickHouse + YT integration with cloud-like model of separate per-project stateless ClickHouse compute clusters 
- Implemented YT-specific query engine for running distributed queries over YT tables
- Set up user support in a community chat
- Devised convenient Python API and CLI for working with ClickHouse within YT
- Worked on integration of various BI tools (Tableau, DataLens BI) with YT using CHYT as a connector
- Implemented efficient interop between ClickHouse columnar in-memory data representation and YT columnar format, and also interop between ClickHouse and YT type systems (including composite types)
- Added support for sorted JOIN scheme to ClickHouse which utilizes YT-specific notion of table sort order
- Written CHYT documentation (reference, architecture and user guide)

Misc achievements:
- Helped with migration of YT code base from separate GitHub repository to Yandex main monorepository, Arcadia
- Became the YT release manager, working on release cycle which involves tens of testing and production YT clusters and tens of involved developers; reducing release cycle from 6 months to 3-4 months.
profile_positions.title: Senior Software Engineer

profile_positions.description:
During this period I became code owner and primary developer of MapReduce control plane, which is a complex state machine implementing persistence and data flow logic of MapReduce computations. Aside from software engineering, I became involved in hiring and techleading interns, and authoring Yandex Algorithm competitions.

Engineering:
- Complete rewriting of MapReduce controllers in order to separate job state machine from job input construction logic; the latter became a separate primitive with clear interface and lots of unittests (~10k LoC of test cases), which was later re-used in various projects within YT and outside it
- Adaptive job memory limit tuner, which tries to lower RAM guarantee for jobs basing on previous run statistics in order to increase cluster-wide RAM utilization
- Userspace core dump writer based on Google Coredumper library for graceful assertion handling
- Auto-merge functionality, which enlarges output data chunk sizes by running extra merge jobs on demand; as a result, chunk fragmentation and chunk quota violation became much less of an issue for users
- Job revival, a protocol for persistence of already running MapReduce jobs in case of operation controller transfer to another host; this later became a topic for a talk on HighLoad++ 2019 conference
- P2P protocol for proactive hot data replication to reduce IO bottlenecks
- Devised and injected memory tagging logic into internal Yandex memory allocator, for annotating memory allocations with a 16-bit tags and collecting per-tag memory statistics; this was used for granular memory control and OOM killer in a process hosting a thousands of MapReduce operation controllers.

Project and technical managing:
- Mentoring SWE intern in own project - graceful migration of YT maintenance notification system onto newly created company-wide notification service
- Authoring problems for Yandex Algorithm 2016-2018, coordinating and managing problem authors for Yandex Algorithm 2017 competition
profile_positions.title: Software Engineer

profile_positions.description:
- A number of optimizations and improvements to various formats supported in YT
- A Hermes microservice for tracking software versions deployed to ten-ish YT clusters and notifying subscribed users about code deployment to the clusters of interest
- Own project: shell autocompletion for YT CLI
profile_positions.title: Software Engineering Intern

profile_positions.description: I was the round coordinator of CodeForces that is the largest competitive programming platform in the world​. I was working with problem authors that wanted to hold a contest by evaluating their problems and writing solutions. I was responsible for the contest schedule and problem quality.
profile_positions.title: Round Coordinator

profile_positions.description: I coded high-loaded internal service for enriching search results with entities from the knowledge graph for the further search quality evaluation.
profile_positions.title: Software Engineering Intern

profile_positions.description:
I worked as a teacher assistant at the AESC MSU department of informatics. I was responsible for
preparing students for the all­-Russian high school student Olympiad. AESC MSU is a boarding high school founded by Kolmogorov, affiliated with Moscow State University.
profile_positions.title: Assistant teacher
